head.title: Private Sector; Answering His Own Tough Questions

hedline.hl1: Private Sector; Answering His Own Tough Questions

abstract.p: Chrysler Group president, Dieter Zetsche, answers his own tough questions in appearance before Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Detroit; photo (M)

block.p: Dieter Zetsche, the Chrysler Group president, assumed that he would be pelted with questions last week when he addressed the Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Detroit.

Dieter Zetsche, the Chrysler Group president, assumed that he would be pelted with questions last week when he addressed the Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Detroit.

After all, Chrysler's fortunes have plummeted since the 1998 merger of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler that was supposed to create a global powerhouse. DaimlerChrysler executives in Germany have come in for local wrath because the deal did not turn out to be the promised ''merger of equals.''
Mr. Zetsche, 48, sent from Germany last fall, has been under pressure because his rescue plan included layoffs and plant closings.

But instead of waiting to be grilled, Mr. Zetsche quizzed himself. Are Germans taking over Chrysler? No, he said, he and Chrysler's chief operating officer, Wolfgang Bernhard, are the only two senior managers from abroad. ''It's just Wolfgang and me,'' he told the audience of 400 community and business leaders.
Why did so many of Chrysler's American managers leave? Some sought new opportunities. ''At all companies, executives are moving all the time,'' Mr. Zetsche said.

Mr. Zetsche's appearance impressed Ralph J. Gerson, an executive vice president at Guardian Industries, an auto supplier. ''It's very important, given the dark history'' of the merger, Mr. Gerson said.
